Tiene más de 400 perros rescatados en Xalapa; hay que apoyarla
Algunos de los perros que se encuentran en el albergue han sido víctimas de violencia extrema o accidentes vehiculares
02 Nov 2019 by Itzel Molina | Diario de Xalapa
Xalapa, Ver.- La propietaria del refugio canino “Ada Azul”, Ada Fernández invitó a la población a adoptar un perro, ya que cuenta con más de 400 ejemplares rescatados
La labor de rescate inició hace varios años en Xalapa, ante la cantidad de animales en situación de calle que existían, añadió.
Algunos de los perros que se encuentran en el albergue de Ada han sido víctimas de violencia extrema o accidentes vehiculares.
Con el paso de los años el número de perritos que llegaron al albergue fue creciendo, por lo que a la fecha se tienen más de 400, todos rescatados de la calle, por lo que se les busca dar la oportunidad de encontrar un hogar.
Para el sustento de estos perritos se requieren al menos 300 kilos de croquetas diarias, así como cloro, champú y jabones para bañarlos.
El albergue ha sobrevivido mediante donaciones, ya sea de alimento o para las campañas de esterilización, todos los perritos son esterilizados, vacunados y desparasitados antes de ingresar al albergue, por ello se debe tener la confianza de que será una buena decisión llevarlos a casa
Para quienes quieran colaborar con esta noble causa, se recuerda que las instalaciones del albergue Ada Azul se encuentran en Arco Sur 122 junto a los juzgados del Tribunal Superior de Justicia de la Federación.

They paint a swastika in Jewish monument in Bogotá
02 Nov 2019 by lapatria.com

Government rejected the fact.

Efe | THE PATRIA | Bogota
Unidentified people broke down a Jewish candelabrum (Menorah) installed in northern Bogotá by painting a swastika at its base, which led to the rejection of the religious community in the country, diplomatic sources denounced.
The Israeli ambassador to Bogotá, Christian Cantor, posted a photo of the monument on his social networks and expressed his rejection of what happened in the work of the painter and sculptor Joel Grossman.
"This type of disgusting violence and hatred against our people does not take place in a country as dear as Colombia. We reaffirm our commitment to the firm fight against anti-Semitism," Cantor said of the Menorah monument.
The Colombian Foreign Ministry expressed its rejection in a statement and said that the Government condemns this type of facts and expressions of intolerance and hatred, while reiterating Colombia's respect, solidarity and gratitude to the people of Israel.
For his part, the director of the Confederation of Jewish Communities of Colombia, Marcos Peckel, described in his Twitter account as "demented, unacceptable and highly offensive" painted on the monument, since this is a "symbol of peace."
Last May, the former Colombian president and Nobel Peace Prize winner Juan Manuel Santos apologized to the Jewish community for comparing a law on Israel related to the Palestinians with a law on Nazi Germany.
In a letter sent to Peckel, Santos acknowledged that he was wrong in an interview with the Caracol Radio Hour 20 program, in which he said: "The Israeli parliament passed an oprobious law where it treats Palestinians living in Israel similar to the law that the Germans passed against the Jews in the 1930s. "
After the controversy, the ex-president assured that there is nothing that can be compared with the suffering of the Jewish people during the holocaust.
In August 2018, Colombia became the last South American country to recognize Palestine as a free, independent and sovereign State, a decision that was taken by the Government of Juan Manuel Santos just four days before the end of his presidential term.
